As a student entering the tech industry, Iâ€™ve witnessed the growing permanence of remote software engineering. What started as a pandemic workaround has evolved into a powerful model for productivity, collaboration, and inclusion.A recent GitLab Remote Work Report (2023) revealed that 86% of developers feel more productive working remotely, and 80% prefer it to in-office setups. For students, these numbers arenâ€™t just statsâ€”they represent opportunity. Remote work is giving us access to real-world experiences we wouldnâ€™t otherwise have.One of my most meaningful remote experiences was developing a Unix-style shell in C, called atlas-simple_shell. This wasnâ€™t a tutorial projectâ€”it was a fully functional command-line interpreter with features like piping, error handling, and environment variable management.What made this experience powerful wasnâ€™t just the codeâ€”it was how my team and I collaborated. All of us were based in the same city, but none of us worked in the same place. Some preferred early mornings at the library, others coded from home or cafÃ©s late into the night. Remote work let each of us stay in our flow and schedule.We used GitHub to manage version control and pull requests, and met via Zoom when syncs were needed. Our coordination through Slack meant we could keep momentum without waiting on each other. This asynchronous setup didnâ€™t just help the project succeedâ€”it taught us to communicate, document, and organize like professionals.Remote collaboration doesnâ€™t lower expectationsâ€”it raises them. Working asynchronously demands better communication, ownership, and planning. Hereâ€™s what remote professionalism meant for me:Clear Communication: Writing clean, detailed pull request messages and updates.Accountability: Sticking to deadlines, even if we werenâ€™t being directly managed.Technical Documentation: Creating READMEs and code comments that made the project usable and understandable for everyone on the team.Collaboration Without Co-location: Knowing when to push forward independently vs. when to sync with teammates.These habits are exactly what top engineering teams need, whether remote or not.Remote software engineering has changed how students like me access experience and build skills. I didnâ€™t need a physical internship to practice real collaboration. I learned how to handle source control in a team, maintain project structure, and debug othersâ€™ code.Even more exciting is how inclusive this model is. When location is no longer a constraint, more people can participate. Students from different backgrounds, responsibilities, and living situations can still contributeâ€”and thrive.Remote work helped me work smarter, stay motivated, and build something meaningful with others on my own terms. Itâ€™s a practice Iâ€™m taking into the professional world with confidence.SourcesGitLab Remote Work Report 2023 â€“ GitLabStack Overflow Blog â€“ How Remote Engineering Teams Can Succeed

IN-OFFICE  vs  REMOTE LEGAL INTERNSHIPSYou applied for a virtual remote internship. You got selected.You updated your LinkedIn.But waitâ€¦ Is a remote legal internship actually worth it?Will recruiters value it?Will you learn real skills?Orwill you just become an email-forwarding intern?Here's the verdict:1âƒ£ Learning curve: Hands-on work vs. Screen workğŸ“ In-office internship = Real-world exposure. You watch senior lawyers argue in court, draft real contracts, and interact with clients. ğŸ“ Remote internship = Good for research & drafting. But you miss out on the action. No court visits, no last-minute client calls.âœ… Example: A litigation intern working in an office learns court procedures.A remote intern?They research case laws but never see them argued in real time.ğŸ’¡If you want practical legal skills, in-office wins. If you love research & writing, remote works.2âƒ£ Networking: Coffee chats vs. Cold EmailsğŸ“ In-office internship = You interact with seniors, learn from casual conversations, and build real relationships. ğŸ“ Remote internship = You connect via emails & Zoom.Itâ€™s harder to make a lasting impression.âœ… Example: An intern at a corporate firm grabs coffee with a partner, gets career advice, and later, a job referral.A remote intern?Sends a â€œThank you for the opportunityâ€ email and getsâ€¦ seen-zoned.ğŸ’¡ Want strong industry connections? In-office internships are gold.3âƒ£ Work-life balance: Hustle vs. FlexibilityğŸ“ In-office internship = Fixed schedule. Long hours. Commuting stress. ğŸ“ Remote internship = Work from anywhere. More control over time.âœ… Example: A remote intern can attend classes and work at night. An in-office intern?Running from courtrooms to college like a legal Usain Bolt.ğŸ’¡ If you need flexibility, remote internships win. If you want the real law firm experience, in-office is unbeatable.4âƒ£ CV value: "Interned" vs. "Actually worked"ğŸ“ In-office internships = More credibility. Lawyers trust work done in a law firm setting. ğŸ“ Remote internships = Skeptical recruiters.Did you really work, or just edit PDFs?âœ… Example: A hiring partner sees two CVs:One intern worked physically in a top-tier firm.One intern remotely with a legal blog.Who gets the callback?You know the answer. ğŸ˜‰ğŸ’¡ Want a CV that stands out? In-office internships have more weight.5âƒ£ Which one teaches you more? ğŸ“Remote internships are great for research, writing, and learning at your own pace. ğŸ“ In-office internships teach real legal workâ€”drafting, client handling, and actual practice.âœ… Example:A litigation intern in court learns how judges react to arguments.A remote intern reads judgments but never sees them applied.ğŸ’¡ If you want to become a lawyer, in-office internships will teach you more.ğŸ¯ Final advice?ğŸ“Œ If youâ€™re in 1st or 2nd year, remote internships help build skills. ğŸ“Œ If youâ€™re in 3rd year or beyond, prioritize in-office internships.Real exposure > Virtual learning.hashtag#law

Core JavaDay-19Encapsulation:---------------------Encapsulation is a process of making variables are private and accessing through methodsÂ public those are getters and setters.-If we declare all variables are private, then it is tightly coupled class.-If we declare any one variable is not private, then it is loosely coupled class.-setters-Always declare return type as void.-getters-Always declare its respective return type and does't have any parameter.Benefits of Encapsulation:1. Data Hiding: Encapsulation protects the data from unauthorized access.2.Increased Flexibility: It allows the internal implementation to be changed without affecting the external code.3.Improved Maintainability:  It helps in maintaining the code by keeping the data private and providing controlled access to modify it. 4.Reusability:  Encapsulated code is easier to reuse in other parts of the application.5.Testing: Encapsulated units can be tested independently.BILLA HEMANTH10000 Coders

PRE-QUALIFICATION METHODOLOGY â€“ VETASSESS Skills Assessment!Pre-qualification experience refers to work experience gained prior to completing your formal qualification (such as a diploma or bachelorâ€™s degree). VETASSESS may consider this experience for a skills assessment, but only if specific additional requirements are met.For occupations classified under Groups B, C, and D, applicants must demonstrate:â€¢ A period of highly relevant pre-qualification employment at the required skill level, andâ€¢ At least one year of highly relevant employment performed within the last five years before applying.The additional pre-qualification experience required is as follows:â€¢ Group B: At least five extra years of relevant employment prior to the qualification.â€¢ Groups C and D: At least three extra years of relevant employment prior to the qualification.This methodology allows applicants who have been working in the field before completing their studies to still be eligible for a positive skills assessment â€” provided they clearly demonstrate the employment was at the required skill level.For Example: Civil Engineering Draftsperson (Group C Occupation)â€¢ Qualification: Bachelor of Mechanical Engineeringâ€¢ Work Experience: Involved in civil engineering drafting projects even before completing the bachelor's degreeDespite holding a degree in a different discipline, the candidate has:â€¢ 3 years of highly relevant pre-qualification work experience, andâ€¢ 1 year of relevant employment within the last 5 yearsThis makes them eligible for a positive skills assessment as a Civil Engineering Draftsperson under Group C through VETASSESS, using the pre-qualification employment pathway.Kind regards!Zara Wangchuk Senior Skills Assessment expert +61 481 607 652/ +61 483 931 112zara@cdrwritersaustralia.comFacebook- https://lnkd.in/gNBGSxBJLinkedIn-https: https://lnkd.in/gMahbYE6WhatsApp Group- https://lnkd.in/gedzveHJ

As a student entering the tech industry, Iâ€™ve witnessed the growing permanence of remote software engineering. What started as a pandemic workaround has evolved into a powerful model for productivity, collaboration, and inclusion.A recent GitLab Remote Work Report (2023) revealed that 86% of developers feel more productive working remotely, and 80% prefer it to in-office setups. For students, these numbers arenâ€™t just statsâ€”they represent opportunity. Remote work is giving us access to real-world experiences we wouldnâ€™t otherwise have.One of my most meaningful remote experiences was developing a Unix-style shell in C, called atlas-simple_shell. This wasnâ€™t a tutorial projectâ€”it was a fully functional command-line interpreter with features like piping, error handling, and environment variable management.What made this experience powerful wasnâ€™t just the codeâ€”it was how my team and I collaborated. All of us were based in the same city, but none of us worked in the same place. Some preferred early mornings at the library, others coded from home or cafÃ©s late into the night. Remote work let each of us stay in our flow and schedule.We used GitHub to manage version control and pull requests, and met via Zoom when syncs were needed. Our coordination through Slack meant we could keep momentum without waiting on each other. This asynchronous setup didnâ€™t just help the project succeedâ€”it taught us to communicate, document, and organize like professionals.Remote collaboration doesnâ€™t lower expectationsâ€”it raises them. Working asynchronously demands better communication, ownership, and planning. Hereâ€™s what remote professionalism meant for me:Clear Communication: Writing clean, detailed pull request messages and updates.Accountability: Sticking to deadlines, even if we werenâ€™t being directly managed.Technical Documentation: Creating READMEs and code comments that made the project usable and understandable for everyone on the team.Collaboration Without Co-location: Knowing when to push forward independently vs. when to sync with teammates.These habits are exactly what top engineering teams need, whether remote or not.Remote software engineering has changed how students like me access experience and build skills. I didnâ€™t need a physical internship to practice real collaboration. I learned how to handle source control in a team, maintain project structure, and debug othersâ€™ code.Even more exciting is how inclusive this model is. When location is no longer a constraint, more people can participate. Students from different backgrounds, responsibilities, and living situations can still contributeâ€”and thrive.Remote work helped me work smarter, stay motivated, and build something meaningful with others on my own terms. Itâ€™s a practice Iâ€™m taking into the professional world with confidence.SourcesGitLab Remote Work Report 2023 â€“ GitLabStack Overflow Blog â€“ How Remote Engineering Teams Can Succeed

IN-OFFICE  vs  REMOTE LEGAL INTERNSHIPSYou applied for a virtual remote internship. You got selected.You updated your LinkedIn.But waitâ€¦ Is a remote legal internship actually worth it?Will recruiters value it?Will you learn real skills?Orwill you just become an email-forwarding intern?Here's the verdict:1âƒ£ Learning curve: Hands-on work vs. Screen workğŸ“ In-office internship = Real-world exposure. You watch senior lawyers argue in court, draft real contracts, and interact with clients. ğŸ“ Remote internship = Good for research & drafting. But you miss out on the action. No court visits, no last-minute client calls.âœ… Example: A litigation intern working in an office learns court procedures.A remote intern?They research case laws but never see them argued in real time.ğŸ’¡If you want practical legal skills, in-office wins. If you love research & writing, remote works.2âƒ£ Networking: Coffee chats vs. Cold EmailsğŸ“ In-office internship = You interact with seniors, learn from casual conversations, and build real relationships. ğŸ“ Remote internship = You connect via emails & Zoom.Itâ€™s harder to make a lasting impression.âœ… Example: An intern at a corporate firm grabs coffee with a partner, gets career advice, and later, a job referral.A remote intern?Sends a â€œThank you for the opportunityâ€ email and getsâ€¦ seen-zoned.ğŸ’¡ Want strong industry connections? In-office internships are gold.3âƒ£ Work-life balance: Hustle vs. FlexibilityğŸ“ In-office internship = Fixed schedule. Long hours. Commuting stress. ğŸ“ Remote internship = Work from anywhere. More control over time.âœ… Example: A remote intern can attend classes and work at night. An in-office intern?Running from courtrooms to college like a legal Usain Bolt.ğŸ’¡ If you need flexibility, remote internships win. If you want the real law firm experience, in-office is unbeatable.4âƒ£ CV value: "Interned" vs. "Actually worked"ğŸ“ In-office internships = More credibility. Lawyers trust work done in a law firm setting. ğŸ“ Remote internships = Skeptical recruiters.Did you really work, or just edit PDFs?âœ… Example: A hiring partner sees two CVs:One intern worked physically in a top-tier firm.One intern remotely with a legal blog.Who gets the callback?You know the answer. ğŸ˜‰ğŸ’¡ Want a CV that stands out? In-office internships have more weight.5âƒ£ Which one teaches you more? ğŸ“Remote internships are great for research, writing, and learning at your own pace. ğŸ“ In-office internships teach real legal workâ€”drafting, client handling, and actual practice.âœ… Example:A litigation intern in court learns how judges react to arguments.A remote intern reads judgments but never sees them applied.ğŸ’¡ If you want to become a lawyer, in-office internships will teach you more.ğŸ¯ Final advice?ğŸ“Œ If youâ€™re in 1st or 2nd year, remote internships help build skills. ğŸ“Œ If youâ€™re in 3rd year or beyond, prioritize in-office internships.Real exposure > Virtual learning.hashtag#law

Core JavaDay-19Encapsulation:---------------------Encapsulation is a process of making variables are private and accessing through methodsÂ public those are getters and setters.-If we declare all variables are private, then it is tightly coupled class.-If we declare any one variable is not private, then it is loosely coupled class.-setters-Always declare return type as void.-getters-Always declare its respective return type and does't have any parameter.Benefits of Encapsulation:1. Data Hiding: Encapsulation protects the data from unauthorized access.2.Increased Flexibility: It allows the internal implementation to be changed without affecting the external code.3.Improved Maintainability:  It helps in maintaining the code by keeping the data private and providing controlled access to modify it. 4.Reusability:  Encapsulated code is easier to reuse in other parts of the application.5.Testing: Encapsulated units can be tested independently.BILLA HEMANTH10000 Coders

PRE-QUALIFICATION METHODOLOGY â€“ VETASSESS Skills Assessment!Pre-qualification experience refers to work experience gained prior to completing your formal qualification (such as a diploma or bachelorâ€™s degree). VETASSESS may consider this experience for a skills assessment, but only if specific additional requirements are met.For occupations classified under Groups B, C, and D, applicants must demonstrate:â€¢ A period of highly relevant pre-qualification employment at the required skill level, andâ€¢ At least one year of highly relevant employment performed within the last five years before applying.The additional pre-qualification experience required is as follows:â€¢ Group B: At least five extra years of relevant employment prior to the qualification.â€¢ Groups C and D: At least three extra years of relevant employment prior to the qualification.This methodology allows applicants who have been working in the field before completing their studies to still be eligible for a positive skills assessment â€” provided they clearly demonstrate the employment was at the required skill level.For Example: Civil Engineering Draftsperson (Group C Occupation)â€¢ Qualification: Bachelor of Mechanical Engineeringâ€¢ Work Experience: Involved in civil engineering drafting projects even before completing the bachelor's degreeDespite holding a degree in a different discipline, the candidate has:â€¢ 3 years of highly relevant pre-qualification work experience, andâ€¢ 1 year of relevant employment within the last 5 yearsThis makes them eligible for a positive skills assessment as a Civil Engineering Draftsperson under Group C through VETASSESS, using the pre-qualification employment pathway.Kind regards!Zara Wangchuk Senior Skills Assessment expert +61 481 607 652/ +61 483 931 112zara@cdrwritersaustralia.comFacebook- https://lnkd.in/gNBGSxBJLinkedIn-https: https://lnkd.in/gMahbYE6WhatsApp Group- https://lnkd.in/gedzveHJ

As a student entering the tech industry, Iâ€™ve witnessed the growing permanence of remote software engineering. What started as a pandemic workaround has evolved into a powerful model for productivity, collaboration, and inclusion.A recent GitLab Remote Work Report (2023) revealed that 86% of developers feel more productive working remotely, and 80% prefer it to in-office setups. For students, these numbers arenâ€™t just statsâ€”they represent opportunity. Remote work is giving us access to real-world experiences we wouldnâ€™t otherwise have.One of my most meaningful remote experiences was developing a Unix-style shell in C, called atlas-simple_shell. This wasnâ€™t a tutorial projectâ€”it was a fully functional command-line interpreter with features like piping, error handling, and environment variable management.What made this experience powerful wasnâ€™t just the codeâ€”it was how my team and I collaborated. All of us were based in the same city, but none of us worked in the same place. Some preferred early mornings at the library, others coded from home or cafÃ©s late into the night. Remote work let each of us stay in our flow and schedule.We used GitHub to manage version control and pull requests, and met via Zoom when syncs were needed. Our coordination through Slack meant we could keep momentum without waiting on each other. This asynchronous setup didnâ€™t just help the project succeedâ€”it taught us to communicate, document, and organize like professionals.Remote collaboration doesnâ€™t lower expectationsâ€”it raises them. Working asynchronously demands better communication, ownership, and planning. Hereâ€™s what remote professionalism meant for me:Clear Communication: Writing clean, detailed pull request messages and updates.Accountability: Sticking to deadlines, even if we werenâ€™t being directly managed.Technical Documentation: Creating READMEs and code comments that made the project usable and understandable for everyone on the team.Collaboration Without Co-location: Knowing when to push forward independently vs. when to sync with teammates.These habits are exactly what top engineering teams need, whether remote or not.Remote software engineering has changed how students like me access experience and build skills. I didnâ€™t need a physical internship to practice real collaboration. I learned how to handle source control in a team, maintain project structure, and debug othersâ€™ code.Even more exciting is how inclusive this model is. When location is no longer a constraint, more people can participate. Students from different backgrounds, responsibilities, and living situations can still contributeâ€”and thrive.Remote work helped me work smarter, stay motivated, and build something meaningful with others on my own terms. Itâ€™s a practice Iâ€™m taking into the professional world with confidence.SourcesGitLab Remote Work Report 2023 â€“ GitLabStack Overflow Blog â€“ How Remote Engineering Teams Can Succeed

IN-OFFICE  vs  REMOTE LEGAL INTERNSHIPSYou applied for a virtual remote internship. You got selected.You updated your LinkedIn.But waitâ€¦ Is a remote legal internship actually worth it?Will recruiters value it?Will you learn real skills?Orwill you just become an email-forwarding intern?Here's the verdict:1âƒ£ Learning curve: Hands-on work vs. Screen workğŸ“ In-office internship = Real-world exposure. You watch senior lawyers argue in court, draft real contracts, and interact with clients. ğŸ“ Remote internship = Good for research & drafting. But you miss out on the action. No court visits, no last-minute client calls.âœ… Example: A litigation intern working in an office learns court procedures.A remote intern?They research case laws but never see them argued in real time.ğŸ’¡If you want practical legal skills, in-office wins. If you love research & writing, remote works.2âƒ£ Networking: Coffee chats vs. Cold EmailsğŸ“ In-office internship = You interact with seniors, learn from casual conversations, and build real relationships. ğŸ“ Remote internship = You connect via emails & Zoom.Itâ€™s harder to make a lasting impression.âœ… Example: An intern at a corporate firm grabs coffee with a partner, gets career advice, and later, a job referral.A remote intern?Sends a â€œThank you for the opportunityâ€ email and getsâ€¦ seen-zoned.ğŸ’¡ Want strong industry connections? In-office internships are gold.3âƒ£ Work-life balance: Hustle vs. FlexibilityğŸ“ In-office internship = Fixed schedule. Long hours. Commuting stress. ğŸ“ Remote internship = Work from anywhere. More control over time.âœ… Example: A remote intern can attend classes and work at night. An in-office intern?Running from courtrooms to college like a legal Usain Bolt.ğŸ’¡ If you need flexibility, remote internships win. If you want the real law firm experience, in-office is unbeatable.4âƒ£ CV value: "Interned" vs. "Actually worked"ğŸ“ In-office internships = More credibility. Lawyers trust work done in a law firm setting. ğŸ“ Remote internships = Skeptical recruiters.Did you really work, or just edit PDFs?âœ… Example: A hiring partner sees two CVs:One intern worked physically in a top-tier firm.One intern remotely with a legal blog.Who gets the callback?You know the answer. ğŸ˜‰ğŸ’¡ Want a CV that stands out? In-office internships have more weight.5âƒ£ Which one teaches you more? ğŸ“Remote internships are great for research, writing, and learning at your own pace. ğŸ“ In-office internships teach real legal workâ€”drafting, client handling, and actual practice.âœ… Example:A litigation intern in court learns how judges react to arguments.A remote intern reads judgments but never sees them applied.ğŸ’¡ If you want to become a lawyer, in-office internships will teach you more.ğŸ¯ Final advice?ğŸ“Œ If youâ€™re in 1st or 2nd year, remote internships help build skills. ğŸ“Œ If youâ€™re in 3rd year or beyond, prioritize in-office internships.Real exposure > Virtual learning.hashtag#law

Core JavaDay-19Encapsulation:---------------------Encapsulation is a process of making variables are private and accessing through methodsÂ public those are getters and setters.-If we declare all variables are private, then it is tightly coupled class.-If we declare any one variable is not private, then it is loosely coupled class.-setters-Always declare return type as void.-getters-Always declare its respective return type and does't have any parameter.Benefits of Encapsulation:1. Data Hiding: Encapsulation protects the data from unauthorized access.2.Increased Flexibility: It allows the internal implementation to be changed without affecting the external code.3.Improved Maintainability:  It helps in maintaining the code by keeping the data private and providing controlled access to modify it. 4.Reusability:  Encapsulated code is easier to reuse in other parts of the application.5.Testing: Encapsulated units can be tested independently.BILLA HEMANTH10000 Coders

PRE-QUALIFICATION METHODOLOGY â€“ VETASSESS Skills Assessment!Pre-qualification experience refers to work experience gained prior to completing your formal qualification (such as a diploma or bachelorâ€™s degree). VETASSESS may consider this experience for a skills assessment, but only if specific additional requirements are met.For occupations classified under Groups B, C, and D, applicants must demonstrate:â€¢ A period of highly relevant pre-qualification employment at the required skill level, andâ€¢ At least one year of highly relevant employment performed within the last five years before applying.The additional pre-qualification experience required is as follows:â€¢ Group B: At least five extra years of relevant employment prior to the qualification.â€¢ Groups C and D: At least three extra years of relevant employment prior to the qualification.This methodology allows applicants who have been working in the field before completing their studies to still be eligible for a positive skills assessment â€” provided they clearly demonstrate the employment was at the required skill level.For Example: Civil Engineering Draftsperson (Group C Occupation)â€¢ Qualification: Bachelor of Mechanical Engineeringâ€¢ Work Experience: Involved in civil engineering drafting projects even before completing the bachelor's degreeDespite holding a degree in a different discipline, the candidate has:â€¢ 3 years of highly relevant pre-qualification work experience, andâ€¢ 1 year of relevant employment within the last 5 yearsThis makes them eligible for a positive skills assessment as a Civil Engineering Draftsperson under Group C through VETASSESS, using the pre-qualification employment pathway.Kind regards!Zara Wangchuk Senior Skills Assessment expert +61 481 607 652/ +61 483 931 112zara@cdrwritersaustralia.comFacebook- https://lnkd.in/gNBGSxBJLinkedIn-https: https://lnkd.in/gMahbYE6WhatsApp Group- https://lnkd.in/gedzveHJ

As a student entering the tech industry, Iâ€™ve witnessed the growing permanence of remote software engineering. What started as a pandemic workaround has evolved into a powerful model for productivity, collaboration, and inclusion.A recent GitLab Remote Work Report (2023) revealed that 86% of developers feel more productive working remotely, and 80% prefer it to in-office setups. For students, these numbers arenâ€™t just statsâ€”they represent opportunity. Remote work is giving us access to real-world experiences we wouldnâ€™t otherwise have.One of my most meaningful remote experiences was developing a Unix-style shell in C, called atlas-simple_shell. This wasnâ€™t a tutorial projectâ€”it was a fully functional command-line interpreter with features like piping, error handling, and environment variable management.What made this experience powerful wasnâ€™t just the codeâ€”it was how my team and I collaborated. All of us were based in the same city, but none of us worked in the same place. Some preferred early mornings at the library, others coded from home or cafÃ©s late into the night. Remote work let each of us stay in our flow and schedule.We used GitHub to manage version control and pull requests, and met via Zoom when syncs were needed. Our coordination through Slack meant we could keep momentum without waiting on each other. This asynchronous setup didnâ€™t just help the project succeedâ€”it taught us to communicate, document, and organize like professionals.Remote collaboration doesnâ€™t lower expectationsâ€”it raises them. Working asynchronously demands better communication, ownership, and planning. Hereâ€™s what remote professionalism meant for me:Clear Communication: Writing clean, detailed pull request messages and updates.Accountability: Sticking to deadlines, even if we werenâ€™t being directly managed.Technical Documentation: Creating READMEs and code comments that made the project usable and understandable for everyone on the team.Collaboration Without Co-location: Knowing when to push forward independently vs. when to sync with teammates.These habits are exactly what top engineering teams need, whether remote or not.Remote software engineering has changed how students like me access experience and build skills. I didnâ€™t need a physical internship to practice real collaboration. I learned how to handle source control in a team, maintain project structure, and debug othersâ€™ code.Even more exciting is how inclusive this model is. When location is no longer a constraint, more people can participate. Students from different backgrounds, responsibilities, and living situations can still contributeâ€”and thrive.Remote work helped me work smarter, stay motivated, and build something meaningful with others on my own terms. Itâ€™s a practice Iâ€™m taking into the professional world with confidence.SourcesGitLab Remote Work Report 2023 â€“ GitLabStack Overflow Blog â€“ How Remote Engineering Teams Can Succeed

IN-OFFICE  vs  REMOTE LEGAL INTERNSHIPSYou applied for a virtual remote internship. You got selected.You updated your LinkedIn.But waitâ€¦ Is a remote legal internship actually worth it?Will recruiters value it?Will you learn real skills?Orwill you just become an email-forwarding intern?Here's the verdict:1âƒ£ Learning curve: Hands-on work vs. Screen workğŸ“ In-office internship = Real-world exposure. You watch senior lawyers argue in court, draft real contracts, and interact with clients. ğŸ“ Remote internship = Good for research & drafting. But you miss out on the action. No court visits, no last-minute client calls.âœ… Example: A litigation intern working in an office learns court procedures.A remote intern?They research case laws but never see them argued in real time.ğŸ’¡If you want practical legal skills, in-office wins. If you love research & writing, remote works.2âƒ£ Networking: Coffee chats vs. Cold EmailsğŸ“ In-office internship = You interact with seniors, learn from casual conversations, and build real relationships. ğŸ“ Remote internship = You connect via emails & Zoom.Itâ€™s harder to make a lasting impression.âœ… Example: An intern at a corporate firm grabs coffee with a partner, gets career advice, and later, a job referral.A remote intern?Sends a â€œThank you for the opportunityâ€ email and getsâ€¦ seen-zoned.ğŸ’¡ Want strong industry connections? In-office internships are gold.3âƒ£ Work-life balance: Hustle vs. FlexibilityğŸ“ In-office internship = Fixed schedule. Long hours. Commuting stress. ğŸ“ Remote internship = Work from anywhere. More control over time.âœ… Example: A remote intern can attend classes and work at night. An in-office intern?Running from courtrooms to college like a legal Usain Bolt.ğŸ’¡ If you need flexibility, remote internships win. If you want the real law firm experience, in-office is unbeatable.4âƒ£ CV value: "Interned" vs. "Actually worked"ğŸ“ In-office internships = More credibility. Lawyers trust work done in a law firm setting. ğŸ“ Remote internships = Skeptical recruiters.Did you really work, or just edit PDFs?âœ… Example: A hiring partner sees two CVs:One intern worked physically in a top-tier firm.One intern remotely with a legal blog.Who gets the callback?You know the answer. ğŸ˜‰ğŸ’¡ Want a CV that stands out? In-office internships have more weight.5âƒ£ Which one teaches you more? ğŸ“Remote internships are great for research, writing, and learning at your own pace. ğŸ“ In-office internships teach real legal workâ€”drafting, client handling, and actual practice.âœ… Example:A litigation intern in court learns how judges react to arguments.A remote intern reads judgments but never sees them applied.ğŸ’¡ If you want to become a lawyer, in-office internships will teach you more.ğŸ¯ Final advice?ğŸ“Œ If youâ€™re in 1st or 2nd year, remote internships help build skills. ğŸ“Œ If youâ€™re in 3rd year or beyond, prioritize in-office internships.Real exposure > Virtual learning.hashtag#law

Post Content:
Core JavaDay-19Encapsulation:---------------------Encapsulation is a process of making variables are private and accessing through methodsÂ public those are getters and setters.-If we declare all variables are private, then it is tightly coupled class.-If we declare any one variable is not private, then it is loosely coupled class.-setters-Always declare return type as void.-getters-Always declare its respective return type and does't have any parameter.Benefits of Encapsulation:1. Data Hiding: Encapsulation protects the data from unauthorized access.2.Increased Flexibility: It allows the internal implementation to be changed without affecting the external code.3.Improved Maintainability:  It helps in maintaining the code by keeping the data private and providing controlled access to modify it. 4.Reusability:  Encapsulated code is easier to reuse in other parts of the application.5.Testing: Encapsulated units can be tested independently.BILLA HEMANTH10000 Coders

VETASSESS may consider this experience for a skills assessment, but only if specific additional requirements are met.For occupations classified under Groups B, C, and D, applicants must demonstrate:â€¢ A period of highly relevant pre-qualification employment at the required skill level, andâ€¢ At least one year of highly relevant employment performed within the last five years before applying.The additional pre-qualification experience required is as follows:â€¢ Group B: At least five extra years of relevant employment prior to the qualification.â€¢ Groups C and D: At least three extra years of relevant employment prior to the qualification.This methodology allows applicants who have been working in the field before completing their studies to still be eligible for a positive skills assessment â€” provided they clearly demonstrate the employment was at the required skill level.For Example: Civil Engineering Draftsperson (Group C Occupation)â€¢ Qualification: Bachelor of Mechanical Engineeringâ€¢ Work Experience: Involved in civil engineering drafting projects even before completing the bachelor's degreeDespite holding a degree in a different discipline, the candidate has:â€¢ 3 years of highly relevant pre-qualification work experience, andâ€¢ 1 year of relevant employment within the last 5 yearsThis makes them eligible for a positive skills assessment as a Civil Engineering Draftsperson under Group C through VETASSESS, using the pre-qualification employment pathway.Kind regards!Zara Wangchuk Senior Skills Assessment expert +61 481 607 652/ +61 483 931 112zara@cdrwritersaustralia.comFacebook- https://lnkd.in/gNBGSxBJLinkedIn-https: https://lnkd.in/gMahbYE6WhatsApp Group- https://lnkd.in/gedzveHJ

As a student entering the tech industry, Iâ€™ve witnessed the growing permanence of remote software engineering. What started as a pandemic workaround has evolved into a powerful model for productivity, collaboration, and inclusion.A recent GitLab Remote Work Report (2023) revealed that 86% of developers feel more productive working remotely, and 80% prefer it to in-office setups. For students, these numbers arenâ€™t just statsâ€”they represent opportunity. Remote work is giving us access to real-world experiences we wouldnâ€™t otherwise have.One of my most meaningful remote experiences was developing a Unix-style shell in C, called atlas-simple_shell. This wasnâ€™t a tutorial projectâ€”it was a fully functional command-line interpreter with features like piping, error handling, and environment variable management.What made this experience powerful wasnâ€™t just the codeâ€”it was how my team and I collaborated. All of us were based in the same city, but none of us worked in the same place. Some preferred early mornings at the library, others coded from home or cafÃ©s late into the night. Remote work let each of us stay in our flow and schedule.We used GitHub to manage version control and pull requests, and met via Zoom when syncs were needed. Our coordination through Slack meant we could keep momentum without waiting on each other. This asynchronous setup didnâ€™t just help the project succeedâ€”it taught us to communicate, document, and organize like professionals.Remote collaboration doesnâ€™t lower expectationsâ€”it raises them. Working asynchronously demands better communication, ownership, and planning. Hereâ€™s what remote professionalism meant for me:Clear Communication: Writing clean, detailed pull request messages and updates.Accountability: Sticking to deadlines, even if we werenâ€™t being directly managed.Technical Documentation: Creating READMEs and code comments that made the project usable and understandable for everyone on the team.Collaboration Without Co-location: Knowing when to push forward independently vs. when to sync with teammates.These habits are exactly what top engineering teams need, whether remote or not.Remote software engineering has changed how students like me access experience and build skills. I didnâ€™t need a physical internship to practice real collaboration. I learned how to handle source control in a team, maintain project structure, and debug othersâ€™ code.Even more exciting is how inclusive this model is. When location is no longer a constraint, more people can participate. Students from different backgrounds, responsibilities, and living situations can still contributeâ€”and thrive.Remote work helped me work smarter, stay motivated, and build something meaningful with others on my own terms. Itâ€™s a practice Iâ€™m taking into the professional world with confidence.SourcesGitLab Remote Work Report 2023 â€“ GitLabStack Overflow Blog â€“ How Remote Engineering Teams Can Succeed

No court visits, no last-minute client calls.âœ… Example: A litigation intern working in an office learns court procedures.A remote intern?They research case laws but never see them argued in real time.ğŸ’¡If you want practical legal skills, in-office wins. If you love research & writing, remote works.2âƒ£ Networking: Coffee chats vs. Cold EmailsğŸ“ In-office internship = You interact with seniors, learn from casual conversations, and build real relationships. ğŸ“ Remote internship = You connect via emails & Zoom.Itâ€™s harder to make a lasting impression.âœ… Example: An intern at a corporate firm grabs coffee with a partner, gets career advice, and later, a job referral.A remote intern?Sends a â€œThank you for the opportunityâ€ email and getsâ€¦ seen-zoned.ğŸ’¡ Want strong industry connections? In-office internships are gold.3âƒ£ Work-life balance: Hustle vs. FlexibilityğŸ“ In-office internship = Fixed schedule. Long hours. Commuting stress. ğŸ“ Remote internship = Work from anywhere. More control over time.âœ… Example: A remote intern can attend classes and work at night. An in-office intern?Running from courtrooms to college like a legal Usain Bolt.ğŸ’¡ If you need flexibility, remote internships win. If you want the real law firm experience, in-office is unbeatable.4âƒ£ CV value: "Interned" vs. "Actually worked"ğŸ“ In-office internships = More credibility. Lawyers trust work done in a law firm setting. ğŸ“ Remote internships = Skeptical recruiters.Did you really work, or just edit PDFs?âœ… Example: A hiring partner sees two CVs:One intern worked physically in a top-tier firm.One intern remotely with a legal blog.Who gets the callback?You know the answer. ğŸ˜‰ğŸ’¡ Want a CV that stands out? In-office internships have more weight.5âƒ£ Which one teaches you more? ğŸ“Remote internships are great for research, writing, and learning at your own pace. ğŸ“ In-office internships teach real legal workâ€”drafting, client handling, and actual practice.âœ… Example:A litigation intern in court learns how judges react to arguments.A remote intern reads judgments but never sees them applied.ğŸ’¡ If you want to become a lawyer, in-office internships will teach you more.ğŸ¯ Final advice?ğŸ“Œ If youâ€™re in 1st or 2nd year, remote internships help build skills. ğŸ“Œ If youâ€™re in 3rd year or beyond, prioritize in-office internships.Real exposure > Virtual learning.hashtag#law

Core JavaDay-19Encapsulation:---------------------Encapsulation is a process of making variables are private and accessing through methodsÂ public those are getters and setters.-If we declare all variables are private, then it is tightly coupled class.-If we declare any one variable is not private, then it is loosely coupled class.-setters-Always declare return type as void.-getters-Always declare its respective return type and does't have any parameter.Benefits of Encapsulation:1. Data Hiding: Encapsulation protects the data from unauthorized access.2.Increased Flexibility: It allows the internal implementation to be changed without affecting the external code.3.Improved Maintainability:  It helps in maintaining the code by keeping the data private and providing controlled access to modify it. 4.Reusability:  Encapsulated code is easier to reuse in other parts of the application.5.Testing: Encapsulated units can be tested independently.BILLA HEMANTH10000 Coders

PRE-QUALIFICATION METHODOLOGY â€“ VETASSESS Skills Assessment!Pre-qualification experience refers to work experience gained prior to completing your formal qualification (such as a diploma or bachelorâ€™s degree). VETASSESS may consider this experience for a skills assessment, but only if specific additional requirements are met.For occupations classified under Groups B, C, and D, applicants must demonstrate:â€¢ A period of highly relevant pre-qualification employment at the required skill level, andâ€¢ At least one year of highly relevant employment performed within the last five years before applying.The additional pre-qualification experience required is as follows:â€¢ Group B: At least five extra years of relevant employment prior to the qualification.â€¢ Groups C and D: At least three extra years of relevant employment prior to the qualification.This methodology allows applicants who have been working in the field before completing their studies to still be eligible for a positive skills assessment â€” provided they clearly demonstrate the employment was at the required skill level.For Example: Civil Engineering Draftsperson (Group C Occupation)â€¢ Qualification: Bachelor of Mechanical Engineeringâ€¢ Work Experience: Involved in civil engineering drafting projects even before completing the bachelor's degreeDespite holding a degree in a different discipline, the candidate has:â€¢ 3 years of highly relevant pre-qualification work experience, andâ€¢ 1 year of relevant employment within the last 5 yearsThis makes them eligible for a positive skills assessment as a Civil Engineering Draftsperson under Group C through VETASSESS, using the pre-qualification employment pathway.Kind regards!Zara Wangchuk Senior Skills Assessment expert +61 481 607 652/ +61 483 931 112zara@cdrwritersaustralia.comFacebook- https://lnkd.in/gNBGSxBJLinkedIn-https: https://lnkd.in/gMahbYE6WhatsApp Group- https://lnkd.in/gedzveHJ

As a student entering the tech industry, Iâ€™ve witnessed the growing permanence of remote software engineering. What started as a pandemic workaround has evolved into a powerful model for productivity, collaboration, and inclusion.A recent GitLab Remote Work Report (2023) revealed that 86% of developers feel more productive working remotely, and 80% prefer it to in-office setups. For students, these numbers arenâ€™t just statsâ€”they represent opportunity. Remote work is giving us access to real-world experiences we wouldnâ€™t otherwise have.One of my most meaningful remote experiences was developing a Unix-style shell in C, called atlas-simple_shell. This wasnâ€™t a tutorial projectâ€”it was a fully functional command-line interpreter with features like piping, error handling, and environment variable management.What made this experience powerful wasnâ€™t just the codeâ€”it was how my team and I collaborated. All of us were based in the same city, but none of us worked in the same place. Some preferred early mornings at the library, others coded from home or cafÃ©s late into the night. Remote work let each of us stay in our flow and schedule.We used GitHub to manage version control and pull requests, and met via Zoom when syncs were needed. Our coordination through Slack meant we could keep momentum without waiting on each other. This asynchronous setup didnâ€™t just help the project succeedâ€”it taught us to communicate, document, and organize like professionals.Remote collaboration doesnâ€™t lower expectationsâ€”it raises them. Working asynchronously demands better communication, ownership, and planning. Hereâ€™s what remote professionalism meant for me:Clear Communication: Writing clean, detailed pull request messages and updates.Accountability: Sticking to deadlines, even if we werenâ€™t being directly managed.Technical Documentation: Creating READMEs and code comments that made the project usable and understandable for everyone on the team.Collaboration Without Co-location: Knowing when to push forward independently vs. when to sync with teammates.These habits are exactly what top engineering teams need, whether remote or not.Remote software engineering has changed how students like me access experience and build skills. I didnâ€™t need a physical internship to practice real collaboration. I learned how to handle source control in a team, maintain project structure, and debug othersâ€™ code.Even more exciting is how inclusive this model is. When location is no longer a constraint, more people can participate. Students from different backgrounds, responsibilities, and living situations can still contributeâ€”and thrive.Remote work helped me work smarter, stay motivated, and build something meaningful with others on my own terms. Itâ€™s a practice Iâ€™m taking into the professional world with confidence.SourcesGitLab Remote Work Report 2023 â€“ GitLabStack Overflow Blog â€“ How Remote Engineering Teams Can Succeed

IN-OFFICE  vs  REMOTE LEGAL INTERNSHIPSYou applied for a virtual remote internship. You got selected.You updated your LinkedIn.But waitâ€¦ Is a remote legal internship actually worth it?Will recruiters value it?Will you learn real skills?Orwill you just become an email-forwarding intern?Here's the verdict:1âƒ£ Learning curve: Hands-on work vs. Screen workğŸ“ In-office internship = Real-world exposure. You watch senior lawyers argue in court, draft real contracts, and interact with clients. ğŸ“ Remote internship = Good for research & drafting. But you miss out on the action. No court visits, no last-minute client calls.âœ… Example: A litigation intern working in an office learns court procedures.A remote intern?They research case laws but never see them argued in real time.ğŸ’¡If you want practical legal skills, in-office wins. If you love research & writing, remote works.2âƒ£ Networking: Coffee chats vs. Cold EmailsğŸ“ In-office internship = You interact with seniors, learn from casual conversations, and build real relationships. ğŸ“ Remote internship = You connect via emails & Zoom.Itâ€™s harder to make a lasting impression.âœ… Example: An intern at a corporate firm grabs coffee with a partner, gets career advice, and later, a job referral.A remote intern?Sends a â€œThank you for the opportunityâ€ email and getsâ€¦ seen-zoned.ğŸ’¡ Want strong industry connections? In-office internships are gold.3âƒ£ Work-life balance: Hustle vs. FlexibilityğŸ“ In-office internship = Fixed schedule. Long hours. Commuting stress. ğŸ“ Remote internship = Work from anywhere. More control over time.âœ… Example: A remote intern can attend classes and work at night. An in-office intern?Running from courtrooms to college like a legal Usain Bolt.ğŸ’¡ If you need flexibility, remote internships win. Lawyers trust work done in a law firm setting. ğŸ“ Remote internships = Skeptical recruiters.Did you really work, or just edit PDFs?âœ… Example: A hiring partner sees two CVs:One intern worked physically in a top-tier firm.One intern remotely with a legal blog.Who gets the callback?You know the answer. ğŸ˜‰ğŸ’¡ Want a CV that stands out? In-office internships have more weight.5âƒ£ Which one teaches you more? ğŸ“Remote internships are great for research, writing, and learning at your own pace. ğŸ“ In-office internships teach real legal workâ€”drafting, client handling, and actual practice.âœ… Example:A litigation intern in court learns how judges react to arguments.A remote intern reads judgments but never sees them applied.ğŸ’¡ If you want to become a lawyer, in-office internships will teach you more.ğŸ¯ Final advice?ğŸ“Œ If youâ€™re in 1st or 2nd year, remote internships help build skills. ğŸ“Œ If youâ€™re in 3rd year or beyond, prioritize in-office internships.Real exposure > Virtual learning.hashtag#law

Core JavaDay-19Encapsulation:---------------------Encapsulation is a process of making variables are private and accessing through methodsÂ public those are getters and setters.-If we declare all variables are private, then it is tightly coupled class.-If we declare any one variable is not private, then it is loosely coupled class.-setters-Always declare return type as void.-getters-Always declare its respective return type and does't have any parameter.Benefits of Encapsulation:1. Data Hiding: Encapsulation protects the data from unauthorized access.2.Increased Flexibility: It allows the internal implementation to be changed without affecting the external code.3.Improved Maintainability:  It helps in maintaining the code by keeping the data private and providing controlled access to modify it. 4.Reusability:  Encapsulated code is easier to reuse in other parts of the application.5.Testing: Encapsulated units can be tested independently.BILLA HEMANTH10000 Coders

PRE-QUALIFICATION METHODOLOGY â€“ VETASSESS Skills Assessment!Pre-qualification experience refers to work experience gained prior to completing your formal qualification (such as a diploma or bachelorâ€™s degree). VETASSESS may consider this experience for a skills assessment, but only if specific additional requirements are met.For occupations classified under Groups B, C, and D, applicants must demonstrate:â€¢ A period of highly relevant pre-qualification employment at the required skill level, andâ€¢ At least one year of highly relevant employment performed within the last five years before applying.The additional pre-qualification experience required is as follows:â€¢ Group B: At least five extra years of relevant employment prior to the qualification.â€¢ Groups C and D: At least three extra years of relevant employment prior to the qualification.This methodology allows applicants who have been working in the field before completing their studies to still be eligible for a positive skills assessment â€” provided they clearly demonstrate the employment was at the required skill level.For Example: Civil Engineering Draftsperson (Group C Occupation)â€¢ Qualification: Bachelor of Mechanical Engineeringâ€¢ Work Experience: Involved in civil engineering drafting projects even before completing the bachelor's degreeDespite holding a degree in a different discipline, the candidate has:â€¢ 3 years of highly relevant pre-qualification work experience, andâ€¢ 1 year of relevant employment within the last 5 yearsThis makes them eligible for a positive skills assessment as a Civil Engineering Draftsperson under Group C through VETASSESS, using the pre-qualification employment pathway.Kind regards!Zara Wangchuk Senior Skills Assessment expert +61 481 607 652/ +61 483 931 112zara@cdrwritersaustralia.comFacebook- https://lnkd.in/gNBGSxBJLinkedIn-https: https://lnkd.in/gMahbYE6WhatsApp Group- https://lnkd.in/gedzveHJ

As a student entering the tech industry, Iâ€™ve witnessed the growing permanence of remote software engineering. What started as a pandemic workaround has evolved into a powerful model for productivity, collaboration, and inclusion.A recent GitLab Remote Work Report (2023) revealed that 86% of developers feel more productive working remotely, and 80% prefer it to in-office setups. For students, these numbers arenâ€™t just statsâ€”they represent opportunity. Remote work is giving us access to real-world experiences we wouldnâ€™t otherwise have.One of my most meaningful remote experiences was developing a Unix-style shell in C, called atlas-simple_shell. This wasnâ€™t a tutorial projectâ€”it was a fully functional command-line interpreter with features like piping, error handling, and environment variable management.What made this experience powerful wasnâ€™t just the codeâ€”it was how my team and I collaborated. All of us were based in the same city, but none of us worked in the same place. Some preferred early mornings at the library, others coded from home or cafÃ©s late into the night. Remote work let each of us stay in our flow and schedule.We used GitHub to manage version control and pull requests, and met via Zoom when syncs were needed. Our coordination through Slack meant we could keep momentum without waiting on each other. This asynchronous setup didnâ€™t just help the project succeedâ€”it taught us to communicate, document, and organize like professionals.Remote collaboration doesnâ€™t lower expectationsâ€”it raises them. Working asynchronously demands better communication, ownership, and planning. Hereâ€™s what remote professionalism meant for me:Clear Communication: Writing clean, detailed pull request messages and updates.Accountability: Sticking to deadlines, even if we werenâ€™t being directly managed.Technical Documentation: Creating READMEs and code comments that made the project usable and understandable for everyone on the team.Collaboration Without Co-location: Knowing when to push forward independently vs. when to sync with teammates.These habits are exactly what top engineering teams need, whether remote or not.Remote software engineering has changed how students like me access experience and build skills. I didnâ€™t need a physical internship to practice real collaboration. I learned how to handle source control in a team, maintain project structure, and debug othersâ€™ code.Even more exciting is how inclusive this model is. When location is no longer a constraint, more people can participate. Students from different backgrounds, responsibilities, and living situations can still contributeâ€”and thrive.Remote work helped me work smarter, stay motivated, and build something meaningful with others on my own terms. Itâ€™s a practice Iâ€™m taking into the professional world with confidence.SourcesGitLab Remote Work Report 2023 â€“ GitLabStack Overflow Blog â€“ How Remote Engineering Teams Can Succeed

IN-OFFICE  vs  REMOTE LEGAL INTERNSHIPSYou applied for a virtual remote internship. You got selected.You updated your LinkedIn.But waitâ€¦ Is a remote legal internship actually worth it?Will recruiters value it?Will you learn real skills?Orwill you just become an email-forwarding intern?Here's the verdict:1âƒ£ Learning curve: Hands-on work vs. Screen workğŸ“ In-office internship = Real-world exposure. You watch senior lawyers argue in court, draft real contracts, and interact with clients. ğŸ“ Remote internship = Good for research & drafting. But you miss out on the action. No court visits, no last-minute client calls.âœ… Example: A litigation intern working in an office learns court procedures.A remote intern?They research case laws but never see them argued in real time.ğŸ’¡If you want practical legal skills, in-office wins. If you love research & writing, remote works.2âƒ£ Networking: Coffee chats vs. Cold EmailsğŸ“ In-office internship = You interact with seniors, learn from casual conversations, and build real relationships. ğŸ“ Remote internship = You connect via emails & Zoom.Itâ€™s harder to make a lasting impression.âœ… Example: An intern at a corporate firm grabs coffee with a partner, gets career advice, and later, a job referral.A remote intern?Sends a â€œThank you for the opportunityâ€ email and getsâ€¦ seen-zoned.ğŸ’¡ Want strong industry connections? In-office internships are gold.3âƒ£ Work-life balance: Hustle vs. FlexibilityğŸ“ In-office internship = Fixed schedule. Long hours. Commuting stress. ğŸ“ Remote internship = Work from anywhere. More control over time.âœ… Example: A remote intern can attend classes and work at night. An in-office intern?Running from courtrooms to college like a legal Usain Bolt.ğŸ’¡ If you need flexibility, remote internships win. If you want the real law firm experience, in-office is unbeatable.4âƒ£ CV value: "Interned" vs. "Actually worked"ğŸ“ In-office internships = More credibility. Lawyers trust work done in a law firm setting. ğŸ“ Remote internships = Skeptical recruiters.Did you really work, or just edit PDFs?âœ… Example: A hiring partner sees two CVs:One intern worked physically in a top-tier firm.One intern remotely with a legal blog.Who gets the callback?You know the answer. ğŸ˜‰ğŸ’¡ Want a CV that stands out? In-office internships have more weight.5âƒ£ Which one teaches you more? ğŸ“Remote internships are great for research, writing, and learning at your own pace. ğŸ“ In-office internships teach real legal workâ€”drafting, client handling, and actual practice.âœ… Example:A litigation intern in court learns how judges react to arguments.A remote intern reads judgments but never sees them applied.ğŸ’¡ If you want to become a lawyer, in-office internships will teach you more.ğŸ¯ Final advice?ğŸ“Œ If youâ€™re in 1st or 2nd year, remote internships help build skills. ğŸ“Œ If youâ€™re in 3rd year or beyond, prioritize in-office internships.Real exposure > Virtual learning.hashtag#law

Core JavaDay-19Encapsulation:---------------------Encapsulation is a process of making variables are private and accessing through methodsÂ public those are getters and setters.-If we declare all variables are private, then it is tightly coupled class.-If we declare any one variable is not private, then it is loosely coupled class.-setters-Always declare return type as void.-getters-Always declare its respective return type and does't have any parameter.Benefits of Encapsulation:1. Data Hiding: Encapsulation protects the data from unauthorized access.2.Increased Flexibility: It allows the internal implementation to be changed without affecting the external code.3.Improved Maintainability:  It helps in maintaining the code by keeping the data private and providing controlled access to modify it. 4.Reusability:  Encapsulated code is easier to reuse in other parts of the application.5.Testing: Encapsulated units can be tested independently.BILLA HEMANTH10000 Coders

PRE-QUALIFICATION METHODOLOGY â€“ VETASSESS Skills Assessment!Pre-qualification experience refers to work experience gained prior to completing your formal qualification (such as a diploma or bachelorâ€™s degree). VETASSESS may consider this experience for a skills assessment, but only if specific additional requirements are met.For occupations classified under Groups B, C, and D, applicants must demonstrate:â€¢ A period of highly relevant pre-qualification employment at the required skill level, andâ€¢ At least one year of highly relevant employment performed within the last five years before applying.The additional pre-qualification experience required is as follows:â€¢ Group B: At least five extra years of relevant employment prior to the qualification.â€¢ Groups C and D: At least three extra years of relevant employment prior to the qualification.This methodology allows applicants who have been working in the field before completing their studies to still be eligible for a positive skills assessment â€” provided they clearly demonstrate the employment was at the required skill level.For Example: Civil Engineering Draftsperson (Group C Occupation)â€¢ Qualification: Bachelor of Mechanical Engineeringâ€¢ Work Experience: Involved in civil engineering drafting projects even before completing the bachelor's degreeDespite holding a degree in a different discipline, the candidate has:â€¢ 3 years of highly relevant pre-qualification work experience, andâ€¢ 1 year of relevant employment within the last 5 yearsThis makes them eligible for a positive skills assessment as a Civil Engineering Draftsperson under Group C through VETASSESS, using the pre-qualification employment pathway.Kind regards!Zara Wangchuk Senior Skills Assessment expert +61 481 607 652/ +61 483 931 112zara@cdrwritersaustralia.comFacebook- https://lnkd.in/gNBGSxBJLinkedIn-https: https://lnkd.in/gMahbYE6WhatsApp Group- https://lnkd.in/gedzveHJ

As a student entering the tech industry, Iâ€™ve witnessed the growing permanence of remote software engineering. What started as a pandemic workaround has evolved into a powerful model for productivity, collaboration, and inclusion.A recent GitLab Remote Work Report (2023) revealed that 86% of developers feel more productive working remotely, and 80% prefer it to in-office setups. For students, these numbers arenâ€™t just statsâ€”they represent opportunity. Remote work is giving us access to real-world experiences we wouldnâ€™t otherwise have.One of my most meaningful remote experiences was developing a Unix-style shell in C, called atlas-simple_shell. This wasnâ€™t a tutorial projectâ€”it was a fully functional command-line interpreter with features like piping, error handling, and environment variable management.What made this experience powerful wasnâ€™t just the codeâ€”it was how my team and I collaborated. All of us were based in the same city, but none of us worked in the same place. Some preferred early mornings at the library, others coded from home or cafÃ©s late into the night. Remote work let each of us stay in our flow and schedule.We used GitHub to manage version control and pull requests, and met via Zoom when syncs were needed. Our coordination through Slack meant we could keep momentum without waiting on each other. This asynchronous setup didnâ€™t just help the project succeedâ€”it taught us to communicate, document, and organize like professionals.Remote collaboration doesnâ€™t lower expectationsâ€”it raises them. Working asynchronously demands better communication, ownership, and planning. Hereâ€™s what remote professionalism meant for me:Clear Communication: Writing clean, detailed pull request messages and updates.Accountability: Sticking to deadlines, even if we werenâ€™t being directly managed.Technical Documentation: Creating READMEs and code comments that made the project usable and understandable for everyone on the team.Collaboration Without Co-location: Knowing when to push forward independently vs. when to sync with teammates.These habits are exactly what top engineering teams need, whether remote or not.Remote software engineering has changed how students like me access experience and build skills. I didnâ€™t need a physical internship to practice real collaboration. I learned how to handle source control in a team, maintain project structure, and debug othersâ€™ code.Even more exciting is how inclusive this model is. When location is no longer a constraint, more people can participate. Students from different backgrounds, responsibilities, and living situations can still contributeâ€”and thrive.Remote work helped me work smarter, stay motivated, and build something meaningful with others on my own terms. Itâ€™s a practice Iâ€™m taking into the professional world with confidence.SourcesGitLab Remote Work Report 2023 â€“ GitLabStack Overflow Blog â€“ How Remote Engineering Teams Can Succeed

IN-OFFICE  vs  REMOTE LEGAL INTERNSHIPSYou applied for a virtual remote internship. You got selected.You updated your LinkedIn.But waitâ€¦ Is a remote legal internship actually worth it?Will recruiters value it?Will you learn real skills?Orwill you just become an email-forwarding intern?Here's the verdict:1âƒ£ Learning curve: Hands-on work vs. Screen workğŸ“ In-office internship = Real-world exposure. You watch senior lawyers argue in court, draft real contracts, and interact with clients. ğŸ“ Remote internship = Good for research & drafting. But you miss out on the action. No court visits, no last-minute client calls.âœ… Example: A litigation intern working in an office learns court procedures.A remote intern?They research case laws but never see them argued in real time.ğŸ’¡If you want practical legal skills, in-office wins. If you love research & writing, remote works.2âƒ£ Networking: Coffee chats vs. Cold EmailsğŸ“ In-office internship = You interact with seniors, learn from casual conversations, and build real relationships. ğŸ“ Remote internship = You connect via emails & Zoom.Itâ€™s harder to make a lasting impression.âœ… Example: An intern at a corporate firm grabs coffee with a partner, gets career advice, and later, a job referral.A remote intern?Sends a â€œThank you for the opportunityâ€ email and getsâ€¦ seen-zoned.ğŸ’¡ Want strong industry connections? In-office internships are gold.3âƒ£ Work-life balance: Hustle vs. FlexibilityğŸ“ In-office internship = Fixed schedule. Long hours. Commuting stress. ğŸ“ Remote internship = Work from anywhere. More control over time.âœ… Example: A remote intern can attend classes and work at night. An in-office intern?Running from courtrooms to college like a legal Usain Bolt.ğŸ’¡ If you need flexibility, remote internships win. If you want the real law firm experience, in-office is unbeatable.4âƒ£ CV value: "Interned" vs. "Actually worked"ğŸ“ In-office internships = More credibility. Lawyers trust work done in a law firm setting. ğŸ“ Remote internships = Skeptical recruiters.Did you really work, or just edit PDFs?âœ… Example: A hiring partner sees two CVs:One intern worked physically in a top-tier firm.One intern remotely with a legal blog.Who gets the callback?You know the answer. ğŸ˜‰ğŸ’¡ Want a CV that stands out? In-office internships have more weight.5âƒ£ Which one teaches you more? ğŸ“Remote internships are great for research, writing, and learning at your own pace. ğŸ“ In-office internships teach real legal workâ€”drafting, client handling, and actual practice.âœ… Example:A litigation intern in court learns how judges react to arguments.A remote intern reads judgments but never sees them applied.ğŸ’¡ If you want to become a lawyer, in-office internships will teach you more.ğŸ¯ Final advice?ğŸ“Œ If youâ€™re in 1st or 2nd year, remote internships help build skills. ğŸ“Œ If youâ€™re in 3rd year or beyond, prioritize in-office internships.Real exposure > Virtual learning.hashtag#law

Post Content:
Core JavaDay-19Encapsulation:---------------------Encapsulation is a process of making variables are private and accessing through methodsÂ public those are getters and setters.-If we declare all variables are private, then it is tightly coupled class.-If we declare any one variable is not private, then it is loosely coupled class.-setters-Always declare return type as void.-getters-Always declare its respective return type and does't have any parameter.Benefits of Encapsulation:1. Data Hiding: Encapsulation protects the data from unauthorized access.2.Increased Flexibility: It allows the internal implementation to be changed without affecting the external code.3.Improved Maintainability:  It helps in maintaining the code by keeping the data private and providing controlled access to modify it. 4.Reusability:  Encapsulated code is easier to reuse in other parts of the application.5.Testing: Encapsulated units can be tested independently.BILLA HEMANTH10000 Coders

PRE-QUALIFICATION METHODOLOGY â€“ VETASSESS Skills Assessment!Pre-qualification experience refers to work experience gained prior to completing your formal qualification (such as a diploma or bachelorâ€™s degree). VETASSESS may consider this experience for a skills assessment, but only if specific additional requirements are met.For occupations classified under Groups B, C, and D, applicants must demonstrate:â€¢ A period of highly relevant pre-qualification employment at the required skill level, andâ€¢ At least one year of highly relevant employment performed within the last five years before applying.The additional pre-qualification experience required is as follows:â€¢ Group B: At least five extra years of relevant employment prior to the qualification.â€¢ Groups C and D: At least three extra years of relevant employment prior to the qualification.This methodology allows applicants who have been working in the field before completing their studies to still be eligible for a positive skills assessment â€” provided they clearly demonstrate the employment was at the required skill level.For Example: Civil Engineering Draftsperson (Group C Occupation)â€¢ Qualification: Bachelor of Mechanical Engineeringâ€¢ Work Experience: Involved in civil engineering drafting projects even before completing the bachelor's degreeDespite holding a degree in a different discipline, the candidate has:â€¢ 3 years of highly relevant pre-qualification work experience, andâ€¢ 1 year of relevant employment within the last 5 yearsThis makes them eligible for a positive skills assessment as a Civil Engineering Draftsperson under Group C through VETASSESS, using the pre-qualification employment pathway.Kind regards!Zara Wangchuk Senior Skills Assessment expert +61 481 607 652/ +61 483 931 112zara@cdrwritersaustralia.comFacebook- https://lnkd.in/gNBGSxBJLinkedIn-https: https://lnkd.in/gMahbYE6WhatsApp Group- https://lnkd.in/gedzveHJ

As a student entering the tech industry, Iâ€™ve witnessed the growing permanence of remote software engineering. What started as a pandemic workaround has evolved into a powerful model for productivity, collaboration, and inclusion.A recent GitLab Remote Work Report (2023) revealed that 86% of developers feel more productive working remotely, and 80% prefer it to in-office setups. For students, these numbers arenâ€™t just statsâ€”they represent opportunity. Remote work is giving us access to real-world experiences we wouldnâ€™t otherwise have.One of my most meaningful remote experiences was developing a Unix-style shell in C, called atlas-simple_shell. This wasnâ€™t a tutorial projectâ€”it was a fully functional command-line interpreter with features like piping, error handling, and environment variable management.What made this experience powerful wasnâ€™t just the codeâ€”it was how my team and I collaborated. All of us were based in the same city, but none of us worked in the same place. Some preferred early mornings at the library, others coded from home or cafÃ©s late into the night. Remote work let each of us stay in our flow and schedule.We used GitHub to manage version control and pull requests, and met via Zoom when syncs were needed. Our coordination through Slack meant we could keep momentum without waiting on each other. This asynchronous setup didnâ€™t just help the project succeedâ€”it taught us to communicate, document, and organize like professionals.Remote collaboration doesnâ€™t lower expectationsâ€”it raises them. Working asynchronously demands better communication, ownership, and planning. Hereâ€™s what remote professionalism meant for me:Clear Communication: Writing clean, detailed pull request messages and updates.Accountability: Sticking to deadlines, even if we werenâ€™t being directly managed.Technical Documentation: Creating READMEs and code comments that made the project usable and understandable for everyone on the team.Collaboration Without Co-location: Knowing when to push forward independently vs. when to sync with teammates.These habits are exactly what top engineering teams need, whether remote or not.Remote software engineering has changed how students like me access experience and build skills. I didnâ€™t need a physical internship to practice real collaboration. I learned how to handle source control in a team, maintain project structure, and debug othersâ€™ code.Even more exciting is how inclusive this model is. When location is no longer a constraint, more people can participate. Students from different backgrounds, responsibilities, and living situations can still contributeâ€”and thrive.Remote work helped me work smarter, stay motivated, and build something meaningful with others on my own terms. Itâ€™s a practice Iâ€™m taking into the professional world with confidence.SourcesGitLab Remote Work Report 2023 â€“ GitLabStack Overflow Blog â€“ How Remote Engineering Teams Can Succeed

Some thoughts on hashtag#remoteWorkI donâ€™t think I need to explain how remote work has evolved in recent years. Before COVID-19 (pre-2021), remote work was a rare privilegeâ€”something only a lucky few could negotiate. But during the pandemic, it became the norm, especially in computer-based fields like software engineering, analytics, and marketing.Over the past few months, however, we've seen increasing pushback. Some companies have gone as far as mandating a full return to the officeâ€”not just hybrid, but five days a week. I wanted to reflect on what feels like a regression.I call it a regression because, had it not been for a global pandemic, many companies would still believe that productivity could only be guaranteed through physical presenceâ€”by clocking in and out, sitting at a desk under watchful eyes. But we proved otherwise. Productivity didnâ€™t tank. The world didnâ€™t stop. The sun didnâ€™t rise from the west.That said, remote work wasnâ€™t without its challenges. Some individuals abused the flexibilityâ€”juggling multiple full-time roles at once and damaging the trust-based relationship needed for remote work to thrive.Iâ€™ve also noticed that some recent graduates, who entered the workforce in this new remote-first world, struggled with engagement. Thrust into what felt like a dream scenario, some lacked the structure or mentorship that in-person environments naturally provideâ€”leading to performance issues.But letâ€™s not allow a few bad examples to overshadow the bigger picture. Remote work may be one of the greatest professional shifts of our time. At least for me, hereâ€™s what itâ€™s meant:1.  I gained back over 2 hours a day from commutingâ€”thatâ€™s 700 hours a year. Less commuting = less stress and wasted energy = more productivity.2. Thatâ€™s time I now spend with my family, myselfâ€”or yes, sometimes, even working.3. Most importantly, I got to watch my baby girl grow up. Every day. From the moment she was born until now, two years later, Iâ€™ve seen her in her element. Thatâ€™s priceless. Itâ€™s something many of our fathers missedâ€”and I donâ€™t think we should repeat that mistake.4. I have more control over my timSo how do we make remote work a win-win?1. Trust, but verify: Build accountability through regular check-ins, clear deliverables, and performance metrics.2. Hybrid mentorship: Pair remote flexibility with in-person or virtual mentorship to support junior talent.3. Cultural investment: Create intentional moments for team bonding and alignmentâ€”digitally or otherwise.4. Results over hours: Focus on outcomes, not desk time. Empower employees to own their time.Remote work isnâ€™t perfectâ€”but neither was the old way. Letâ€™s not lose sight of the enormous good it can bring, when done right. Iâ€™m genuinely grateful to Klarna for embracing this cultureâ€”striking a healthy balance between drive and productivity, while honoring the importance of family and well-being. Letâ€™s evolve, not revert.hashtag#remotework hashtag#futureofwork hashtag#productivity

IN-OFFICE  vs  REMOTE LEGAL INTERNSHIPSYou applied for a virtual remote internship. You got selected.You updated your LinkedIn.But waitâ€¦ Is a remote legal internship actually worth it?Will recruiters value it?Will you learn real skills?Orwill you just become an email-forwarding intern?Here's the verdict:1âƒ£ Learning curve: Hands-on work vs. Screen workğŸ“ In-office internship = Real-world exposure. You watch senior lawyers argue in court, draft real contracts, and interact with clients. ğŸ“ Remote internship = Good for research & drafting. But you miss out on the action. No court visits, no last-minute client calls.âœ… Example: A litigation intern working in an office learns court procedures.A remote intern?They research case laws but never see them argued in real time.ğŸ’¡If you want practical legal skills, in-office wins. If you love research & writing, remote works.2âƒ£ Networking: Coffee chats vs. Cold EmailsğŸ“ In-office internship = You interact with seniors, learn from casual conversations, and build real relationships. ğŸ“ Remote internship = You connect via emails & Zoom.Itâ€™s harder to make a lasting impression.âœ… Example: An intern at a corporate firm grabs coffee with a partner, gets career advice, and later, a job referral.A remote intern?Sends a â€œThank you for the opportunityâ€ email and getsâ€¦ seen-zoned.ğŸ’¡ Want strong industry connections? In-office internships are gold.3âƒ£ Work-life balance: Hustle vs. FlexibilityğŸ“ In-office internship = Fixed schedule. Long hours. Commuting stress. ğŸ“ Remote internship = Work from anywhere. More control over time.âœ… Example: A remote intern can attend classes and work at night. An in-office intern?Running from courtrooms to college like a legal Usain Bolt.ğŸ’¡ If you need flexibility, remote internships win. If you want the real law firm experience, in-office is unbeatable.4âƒ£ CV value: "Interned" vs. "Actually worked"ğŸ“ In-office internships = More credibility. Lawyers trust work done in a law firm setting. ğŸ“ Remote internships = Skeptical recruiters.Did you really work, or just edit PDFs?âœ… Example: A hiring partner sees two CVs:One intern worked physically in a top-tier firm.One intern remotely with a legal blog.Who gets the callback?You know the answer. ğŸ˜‰ğŸ’¡ Want a CV that stands out? In-office internships have more weight.5âƒ£ Which one teaches you more? ğŸ“Remote internships are great for research, writing, and learning at your own pace. ğŸ“ In-office internships teach real legal workâ€”drafting, client handling, and actual practice.âœ… Example:A litigation intern in court learns how judges react to arguments.A remote intern reads judgments but never sees them applied.ğŸ’¡ If you want to become a lawyer, in-office internships will teach you more.ğŸ¯ Final advice?ğŸ“Œ If youâ€™re in 1st or 2nd year, remote internships help build skills. ğŸ“Œ If youâ€™re in 3rd year or beyond, prioritize in-office internships.Real exposure > Virtual learning.hashtag#law
